none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Peeler, November 28, 1879
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from A. J. Peeler, November 28, 1879
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 4 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A. J. Peeler, partner in the law firm Peeler & Maxey, writes to Louis L. McInnis in College Station, Texas regarding concerns about filling the mathematics chair at the college. Peeler expresses worry that repeated board meetings have depleted funds, potentially affecting professor salaries, and suggests that if McInnis demonstrates sufficient qualifications in mathematics, he will advocate for a full professorship at their June meeting. This letter reflects financial constraints and administrative deliberations at an early Texas college during the late 19th century.

body.value:
[Header]

A.J. Peeler.
T.S. Maxey.

Peeler & Maxey,
Attorneys at Law,

Brown & Wiener 69 Leonard St. N.Y.

Austin,Texas. Nov 28th 1879

[Body]

Louis L. McInnis
College Station Tex.
Dr. Sir:
Yours of the 26th
inst, recd. – I am inclined to think, if
we can possibly get along without filling
the chair of mathematics, it would be best
for us to do so. – I very much fear that
the repeated meetings of the Board have
taken enough of the funds to make it a
little doubtful whether all the professors
at the College will get the full amount
coming to them – If you show yourself
fully qualified to successfully and satisfac
torely fill the chair of mathematics, so far
as I am concerned, when we meet next June
I shall consider it a strong argument
in favor of giving you a full professorship.

[Signature]

Very Respectfully
A. J. Peeler
